Description: Fragment of upper part of black-figure painted pottery situla. Designs black on deep buff ground, with incised lines and purple accessories; the black faded. Satyr playing double flute or syrinx and a lyre-player (chelys), between them a lebes on tripod. Purple for hair of satyr, handles and support of bowl, and on sounding box of lyre.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Tell Dafana, Possibly "Qasr", east annex (C), chamber 19 ? or east annex (G), chamber 29 ?
Curator's comments: The pipe player's ear betrays the satyr, and his companion, though seemingly tailless, is presumably a satyr too. For the oversized penis compare the animals of Pls. GB 603, 2 and 604. 8. The purple projection below the bowl is likely to be the end of a spreading stand.

There are numbers pencilled on the back: one is faded and partly illegible, possibly '29 [o...]'; the other is '19 ?'. Whether these numbers are related to the Findspot is unsure. In CVA, Cook assumes that the sherd might come from '19' Cook assumes
Bibliographic references: Vase / Catalogue of Vases in the British Museum (B106.7)
CVA British Museum 8 / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum: Great Britain 13, British Museum 8 (Pl. GB 604, 16 (and Pl. GB 597, 9)) (Group C28)

Weber 2012 / Untersuchungen zur archaischen griechischen Keramik aus anderen ägyptischen Fundorten (TD 268)
Leclère and Spencer 2014 / Tell Dafana Reconsidered: The Archaeology of an Egyptian Frontier Town (p.208)
